## Learning materials

* [Replication and the data diary](https://cronkitedata.github.io/djtextbook/start-data-diary.html) 

* “ [Take an Interviewing Approach to Find Stories in Data](http://mediashift.org/2014/07/take-an-interviewing-approach-to-find-stories-in-data/) ”, by Derek Willis, Mediashift, July 2014.

* ["Basic steps in working with data"](https://datajournalism.com/read/handbook/one/understanding-data/basic-steps-in-working-with-data), the Data Journalism Handbook, Steve Doig, ASU Prof.

* ["Here are the 7 types of stories most often found in data"](https://onlinejournalismblog.com/2020/08/11/here-are-the-7-types-of-stories-most-often-found-in-data/), Paul Bradshaw, Online Journalism Blog, 2020. I'm not sure I agree with these -- they are very focused on visualizations rather than narrative or video stories, but they are a good start. 

## Reminder on spreadsheet skills chapters

Here are the chapters we went through in bootcamp.  There is zero expectation that you have memorized keystrokes! Just memorize where you can look them up. It's much easier.

*  [An Excel Refresher](https://cronkitedata.github.io/djtextbook/xl-refresher.html)  

*  [Excel filter and sort](https://cronkitedata.github.io/djtextbook/xl-filter-sort.html) 

* [Grouping with pivot tables](https://cronkitedata.github.io/djtextbook/xl-pivot.html)

*  [Excel formulas](https://cronkitedata.github.io/djtextbook/xl-formulas.html) 

If you don't remember how to work with fractions, percents, etc., review the [Math appendix](https://cronkitedata.github.io/djtextbook/appendix-math.html) to the course textbook or consult the Numbers in the Newsroom book that is shared in Canvas. 

Try watching Mary Jo Webster's great tutorial on New Yorker comics if you're still a little confused by pivot tables:
